Weiss calculus and unstable thick subcategories

Jul 14, 2019

It’s been a while! In this post, I’d like to contemplate a sort of generalization of Arone’s result, which we discussed in our last post. There, we said that if is the functor obtained by taking the fiber of the “iterated double suspension” , then for , and the map is an equivalence (for an odd sphere) after applying , where . Moreover, itself had a self-map . This is strongly suggestive of thinking of as a “type functor”. In this post, I’d like to develop this analogy further.

To begin, we need to recall a few definitions. Let denote the nerve of the topological category of finite-dimensional complex vector spaces with a Hermitian inner product, and morphisms being linear isometries. Let denote the same category, except where the mapping space is the Thom space of the bundle over whose fiber over is , where denotes the orthogonal complement of in . If is any pointed category, let denote the functor category , and let denote .

Let now be any category. There are inclusions , and this gives a restriction functor . This functor admits a right adjoint ; let . Define the th derivative of to be the object . We shall abusively identify this with ; this functor admits an explicit description. First note that

so it suffices to describe for all .

To obtain this explicit description, let be a pointed functor; then, the composition map gives a map , i.e., a natural transformation . When , we will denote this map by . The fiber of is the functor .

What’s the intuition supposed to be? We will mostly be fixing the category to be the category of pointed spaces. We will always denote objects as , where and . In this case, we have an object given by , sending to , the unit sphere. We will mostly be thinking of objects of not as complex vector spaces, but rather as the associated unit spheres. (Note that is equivalent to the category of spectra .) The th derivative (or, more precisely, ) is then related to Weiss’ functors that we discussed last time via .

From now on, fix a prime , and -localize all spaces and spectra. The functors then satisfies some important finiteness conditions for any fixed :

  • The Goodwillie tower of converges on odd spheres, and it does so exponentially quickly (i.e., is contractible on odd spheres for not a power of );
  • The spectrum is trivial on odd spheres for ; and
  • is trivial on odd spheres if .

Let denote the full subcategory of consisting of functors satisfying the first two conditions, and let denote the subcategory of consisting of functors satisfying all three conditions; note that only the third property imposes some interaction between the in and the value of the functor on odd-dimensional spheres. Let ; the second condition implies that for any , the map is a -equivalence for all . Moreover, if , and is such that , then the third condition implies that is trivial, and so (where is the spectrum whose zeroth space is the -th Goodwillie layer). As we mentioned in the previous post, this generalizes results of Mahowald and Mahowald-Thompson.

Arone’s results show that if we view , then is also in . The proof that satisfies the first property is obvious. For the second property, Arone proves that the cohomology of for any is free over , so kills it for any . (Together, these show that .) The third property (which shows that ) is the claim that is an equivalence.

We would like to say that something similar is true for any ; namely, . First, note that : indeed, the convergence of the Goodwillie tower is immediate; the vanishing of for follows immediately from the five lemma and the existence of the fiber sequence

combined with the fact that and represent the same functor .

We are left with showing the third condition, namely that is trivial for . By the five lemma and the fiber sequence referred to above, we know that vanishes for ; to conclude, we need to be an equivalence. But there is no reason for this to be true in general! Note, however, that if is a fiber sequence in , and is an equivalence for and and all , then it is also an equivalence for and all . In particular, we find, using Arone’s observation that is an equivalence for (which really just boils down to Weiss’ calculation of ), that is an equivalence for any built from by the two-out-of-three property for fiber sequences and retractions (note that is itself closed under the two-out-of-three property for fiber sequences and retractions).

This is looking suspiciously like it’s calling out for an unstable version of the thick subcategory theorem. The analogy, I guess, is supposed to be that Arone-Mahowald and Arone proved unstable analogues of the existence of type spectra (the are supposed to be analogues of Mitchell’s complexes with -free homology), and that Weiss calculus produces unstable analogues (namely, the maps we’ve been denoting ) of self-maps. (I have no idea what the appropriate analogue of the nilpotence theorem should be.) In any case, the final sentence of the previous paragraph seemed to be placing some sort of special role on the functors , but there is no a priori reason for them to be distinguished. This motivates the following conjecture.

Conjecture: Let denote the subcategory of consisting of “finite” functors (i.e., those for which is constructed from via the two-out-of-three property for fiber sequences and retractions), and let denote the subcategory of consisting of those functors for which is nontrivial. Let denote any subcategory of that is closed under the two-out-of-three property for fiber sequences and retractions, and assume that contains an object of . Then .

It would follow from this conjecture that any “finite” is in the subcategory of generated by , so we have . Since the maps are supposed to be analogues of the -self maps, this gives an unstable analogue of the 1980’s style Hopkins-Devinatz-Smith-Ravenel results.

Let us now consider how one might approach the conjecture. We know that . Now, for any (obtained as the value of a functor for some fixed object of ), the map for a fixed gives maps

where the final term in the sequence is the mapping telescope. By assumption, is a finite spectrum. The statement that is nontrivial (i.e., that ) implies that is not -acyclic (but it is -acyclic by virtue of being in ), so it is of type . One can see that this procedure in fact defines a functor . I’d like to better understand and its relation to .

If these two categories are equivalent (which they are not), then the conjecture would be implied by the stable thick subcategory theorem (and therefore be true). I’m not sure how convinced I am about the conjecture, though; I think it’s false, because delooping is not a procedure which can be iterated in general. In any case, I’ll return to this topic in a future post.
